s.text: He has a warm voice, persuasive manner, and a gift for one-liners.
Bryant is succeeded, mercifully, by Hutchinson, who argues the case for obstruction of justice.
Bryant is succeeded, mercifully, by Hutchinson, who argues the case for obstruction of justice.
Bryant is succeeded, mercifully, by Hutchinson, who argues the case for obstruction of justice.
His opening lines strike one of the main themes of the day: bald-faced flattery of the Senate.

(When he describes how Clinton spent late December and early January desperately trying to ensure Lewinsky's silence, Hutchinson mocks the president's current fave phrase, "The president had some time to work.
Perjury is a high crime because it is as bad as bribery.

(The other eight are, in chronological order: 1) The Starr report, 2) the supporting documents, 3) David Schippers' opening presentation to the House Judiciary Committee, 4) Starr's testimony to the committee, 5) Schippers' closing presentation, 6) the committee's final report, 7) the committee's presentation to the full House, and 8) the briefs filed this week by the managers.)
It is just as familiar and soporific as Sensenbrenner's presentation.
It is just as familiar and soporific as Sensenbrenner's presentation.
It is just as familiar and soporific as Sensenbrenner's presentation.
It is just as familiar and soporific as Sensenbrenner's presentation.
It is just as familiar and soporific as Sensenbrenner's presentation.
As the House managers open the prosecution of the president today, the real obstacle they face is not the absence of witnesses or the dismal poll numbers.
As the House managers open the prosecution of the president today, the real obstacle they face is not the absence of witnesses or the dismal poll numbers.
